ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Twice weekly, virtual seminars discussing papers. A couple classes of release time to work on projects toward the end of the semester

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course gave me a deep understanding of both the historical origins of internet protocols, as well as their latest, cutting-edge variations. Building an internet router from scratch forced me to truly understand the most important concepts in networking.

Computer Networking past and present through readings of important papers in the field. Programming in P4 and for the final project Python and P4 for programmable switches. Dealing with a complex software stack to simulate networks.
I developed strong skills using P4 and I learned a lot about how routers and networks are administrated. The breadth of knowledge from this course is great.
I now know P4 and really understand how networks work.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is very refreshing as a CS course, given that it's taught in a reading/discussion format. Overall, I learned a ton about the internet and really enjoyed the discussion and projects.

Strengths are the content, context, and thoughtfulness of Prof. Soule. The workload is also very manageable but I learned a lot (2 paper readings/reviews a week, and 2 projects). ! Its a rewarding class.

Weakness is both projects were heavily underspecified. The class needs a TA or ULAs to guide students in the projects and also provide a more detail spec.
Really liked the engagement of the course. The small form discussions were great for clarifying things about the class and subject matter
I enjoyed the seminar-style paper discussions and appreciated learning a current language. I would have liked some lecture-style lessons and support staff to help with the project.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual seminar worked well, code collaboration was a bit difficult over Zoom and VS Code live Share but manageable.
I think this class was pretty great. The only thing that could be improved was having some parts of the projects in person. I would like to have hands-on experience with it.
Synchronous with cameras on felt like a real class!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you really want to cement your understanding of the internet and build the most rewarding project in the CS department (a router from scratch), then absolutely take this course.

Yes. For the amount of time spent on this class, I learned an outsized amount about both computer networking and routers as a subject but also hands on through programming them. I didnt have the networking prerequisite technically but through reading the papers assigned and discussing in class learned about a breadth of networking topics from TCP/IP to routing protocols and cutting edge data center network architectures and technologies.
Absolutely. The class was fascinating. I learned so much about how networks are dealt with at scale as well as how networking protocols evolved.
I think this was the first time it was open to undergrads. It could use some refinement, but it's a good course for those interested in networks.
